goslarite.Color: Colorless, pinkish, white, greenish, green, blue, green blue, bluish and brownish

hilgardite.Color: Colorless, light pink to reddish brown

hidalgoite.Crystal habit: Massive, porcellaneous to porous; spherulitic aggregates

chlorargyrite.Color: Colorless when fresh; alters to bright chartreuse-green, light yellow, light green, grey, violet-brown on exposure to light

jimthompsonite.Color: Colorless to very light pinkish brown

kainite.Color: Colorless; yellow, brownish, greyish-green, red, violet, blue

keyite.Pleochroism: x: pale blue, y: greenish blue, z: deep blue

kieserite.Crystal habit: Massive, granular; rarely as pyramidal crystals

kosmochlor.Pleochroism: X = yellowish green; Y = blue-green, grass-green; Z = emerald-green

massicot.Color: Yellow may have a red tint

iranite.Space group: Triclinic pedialH-M symbol: (1) Space group: P1

cyanotrichite.Crystal habit: Acicular crystals and fibrous aggregates; incrustations

fluckite.Crystal habit: Crystals prismatic, typically radiating to spherulitic

fluoro-richterite.Color: Brown to brownish-red, rose-red, yellow, grey-brown, also pale to dark green

hagendorfite.Crystal habit: Massive – uniformly indistinguishable crystals forming large masses.

curite.Pleochroism: Visible: X = b = pale yellow, Y = a = light red-orange, Z = c = dark red-orange

albite.Color: White to gray, blueish, greenish, reddish; may be chatoyant

analcime.Color: White, colorless, gray, pink, greenish, yellowish

andradite.Color: Yellow, greenish yellow to emerald-green, dark green; brown, brownish red, brownish yellow; grayish black, black; may be sectored

andradite.Topazolite: transparent to translucent yellow, may show chatoyancy

andalusite.Color: Pink, violet, yellow, green, white, gray; in thin section, colorless to pink or green

apophyllite.Color: Usually white, colorless; also blue, green, brown, yellow, pink, violet

bityite.Color: Pearly white, grayish blue, greenish blue, light brown

bornite.Crystal habit: Granular, massive, disseminated – Crystals pseudocubic, dodecahedral, octahedral

calaverite.Crystal habit: Bladed and slender striated prisms, also massive granular

caryopilite.Color: Reddish brown, tanLight brown to yellow in thin section[1]

cobaltite.Color: Reddish silver white, violet steel gray to black

cobaltite.Twinning: About [111] creating pseudo-cubic forms and striations

coffinite.Color: Black (from organic inclusions; pale to dark brown in thin section

cordierite.Color: Blue, smoky blue, bluish violet; greenish, yellowish brown, gray; colorless to very pale blue in thin section in transmitted light

epidote.Color: Pistachio green, yellow-green, greenish black, brownish-green, green, black

eucryptite.Crystal habit: Rare as euhedral crystals, coarse crystalline aggregates and massive

greenalite.Crystal habit: Rare minute crystals, rounded grains common; as porphyroblasts, oolites

ianbruceite.Dana classification: 42 (hydrated phosphates, arsenates and vanadates containing hydroxyl or halogen)

hubeite.Cleavage: One good cleavage parallel to c-axis

hisingerite.Crystal habit: Massive, compact; acicular, may be minutely spherical.

hibonite.Color: Brownish black to black; reddish brown in thin fragments; blue in meteorite occurrence

junitoite.Color: Colorless, milk-white, or colored due to alteration[2]

crocoite.Color: Orange, red, yellow; orange-red in transmitted light.

microcline.Color: White, grey, greyish yellow, yellowish, tan, salmon-pink, bluish green, green.
microcline.Crystal habit: Can be anhedral or euhedral. Grains are commonly elongate with a tabular appearance. May contain lamellae which formed from exsolved albite.
microcline.Twinning:
Typically displays albite twinning and pericline twinning. This combination leads to a grid pattern, hence microcline displays gridiron twinning. Can also display carlsbad twinning, simple twins, or lack twinning altogether. Lamellae in microcline are discontinuous and "pinch and swell".
Photomicrograph of thin section of microcline showing crosshatched crystal twinning (in cross polarized light)
microcline.Cleavage: Has perfect cleavage parallel to {001} and good cleavage on {010}. Cleavages intersect at 90°41'. It can be difficult to see cleavage in thin section due to microcline's low relief.
microcline.Diagnostic features: Gridiron twinning distinguishes microcline from other feldspars. Distinguishable from plagioclase because the lamellae in plagioclase are continuous and do not "pinch and swell."
microcline.Alters to: Commonly alters to sericite or clay.

brookite.Color: Deep red, reddish brown, yellowish brown, brown, or black

brookite.Pleochroism: Very weak, yellowish, reddish, orange to brown

brazilianite.Crystal habit: Prismatic crystals, may be radially-fibrous or globular druses

brucite.Color: White, pale green, blue, gray; honey-yellow to brownish red
brucite.Crystal habit: Tabular crystals; platy or foliated masses and rosettes – fibrous to massive

fluorapatite.Color: Sea-green, violet, purple, blue, pink, yellow, brown, white, colorless, may be zoned

carnallite.Twinning: By pressure, polysynthetic twin lamellae can be developed

chalcophyllite.Crystal habit: Crystals platy and six-sided, also as rosettes, drusy, foliated or massive.
chalcophyllite.Solubility: Soluble in acids and in ammonia
chalcophyllite.Other characteristics: Can be partially dehydrated. Alters to chrysocolla. Nonfluorescent, not radioactive

oldhamite.Alters to: Tarnishes on exposure to moist air

grossular.Color:
light to dark green, light to dark yellow to reddish brown, brown, orange, red, yellow, green, white, occasionally translucent to opaque pink. It is also but rarely 
found in colorless form[2]
grossular.Optical properties: Single refractive, often anomalous double refractive[2]
grossular.Ultraviolet: near colorless to light green – inert to weak orange in longwave and weak yellow-orange in shortwave; yellow – inert to weak orange in longwave and shortwave[2]
grossular.Absorption spectra: Hessonite sometimes shows bands at 407 and 430 nm
grossular.Rosolite: translucent to opaque pink grossularite crystals in marble from Mexico

patrónite.Color: Lead-gray on fresh surfaces to gray-black after exposure to air
patrónite.Crystal habit: Occurs as columnar crystal aggregates and in massive form

prehnite.Color: Colorless to gray to yellow, yellow-green or white
prehnite.Ultraviolet: Fluorescent, short UV=blue white mild peach, long UV=yellow

purpurite.Color: Brownish black, violet, dark pink, dark red, reddish purple

pyrope.Color: Blood red to black red, red, orange red, pink,  some varieties are very dark, almost black, while others can take tones of purple to purple red, Some chromium-rich pyropes are thermochromic, becoming green when heated.[2]
pyrope.Crystal habit: Euhedra typically display rhombic dodecahedral form, but trapezohedra are not uncommon, and hexoctahedra are seen in some rare samples. Massive and granular forms also occur.
pyrope.Optical properties: Single refractive, often anomalous double refractive[3]
pyrope.Refractive index: 1.74 normal, but ranges from 1.714 to over 1.742[3]
pyrope.Birefringence: Isotropic, appears black in cross-polarized light
pyrope.Absorption spectra: broad band at 564 nm with cutoff at 440 to 445 nm. Fine gem quality pyropes may show chromium lines in the red end of the spectrum
pyrope.Solubility: Insoluble in water, weakly soluble in HF

salammoniac.Color: Colorless, white, pale gray; may be pale yellow to brown, if impure.
salammoniac.Crystal habit: Crystals skeletal or dendritic; massive, encrustations

ferberite.Color: Black, dark brown in transmitted light
ferberite.Twinning: Contact or interpenetrant or lamellar twins

chloritoid.Color: Dark gray, greenish gray, greenish black
chloritoid.Crystal habit:
Tabular pseudohexagonal crystals; rosettes, commonly coarsely foliated with foliae
typically curved or bent; also massive
chloritoid.Twinning: Common on {001}, polysynthetic may be lamellar
chloritoid.Cleavage: Perfect on {001}, distinct on {110}; parting on {010}
chloritoid.Streak: White, grayish, or very slightly greenish
chloritoid.Pleochroism: X = olive-green to yellow; Y = grayish blue to blue; Z = colorless to pale greenish yellow

sapphirine.Colour: Light to dark blue or green, white, gray, pale red, yellow
sapphirine.Pleochroism: X = colorless, pale reddish, yellowish green, pale yellow; Y = sky-blue, lavender-blue, bluish green; Z = blue, sapphire-blue, dark blue

sillimanite.Color: Colourless or white to grey, also brown, yellow, yellow-green, grey-green, blue-green, blue; colourless in thin section
sillimanite.Pleochroism: Colourless to pale brown to yellow

jacobsite.Category: Oxide minerals Spinel group Spinel structural group
jacobsite.Crystal habit: Disseminated to massive, rarely as octahedral crystals
jacobsite.Twinning: Spinel law, flattened on {111} or lamellar

smithsonite.Color: White, grey, yellow, green to apple-green, blue, pink, purple, bluish grey, and brown
smithsonite.Crystal habit: Uncommon as crystals, typically botryoidal, reniform, spherulitic; stalactitic, earthy, compact massive
smithsonite.Ultraviolet: May fluoresce pale green or pale blue under UV

serandite.Twinning: Around [010] composition plane {100}, less commonly contact twin on {110}
serandite.Luster: Vitreous to greasy; fibrous aggregates are dull to silky[2]

sylvite.Color:
Colorless to white, pale gray, pale blue; may be yellowish red
to red due to hematite inclusions
sylvite.Crystal habit: As cubes and octahedra; columnar, in crusts, coarse granular, massive

talmessite.Colour: White or colourless, pale green (nickel-rich) or brownish or pink (cobalt-rich).  Colourless in transmitted light.
talmessite.Pleochroism: The cobaltoan variety is  pleochroic, colourless to pale rose[5]
talmessite.Other characteristics: Not radioactive.[2]  It loses water of crystallisation at 450o[5]

lavendulan.Formula: NaCaCu5(AsO4)4Cl.5H2O  Usually with some K, Co and Ni[1]
lavendulan.Crystal habit: Thin botryoidal crusts of minute radiating fibers or thin rectangular, pseudo-orthorhombic plates[1][3]
lavendulan.Luster: Vitreous to waxy, satiny in aggregates
lavendulan.Pleochroism: O = pale blue to pale greenish blue, E = blue to greenish blue

shigaite.Pleochroism: Distinct; O = yellow; E = very pale yellow[5]

stibarsen.Color: White, gray, grayish white, reddish white

strengite.Color: Colorless, pale violet, deep violet, red, carmine red, greenish white

lazulite.Color: Azure, sky blue, bluish white, yellow-green, blue-green, rarely green
lazulite.Crystal habit: Tabular, acute to stubby bipyramidal crystals; granular, massive
lazulite.Cleavage: Poor to good on {110}, indistinct on {101}
lazulite.Diaphaneity: Transparent to translucent to nearly opaque
lazulite.Pleochroism: Strong: X = colorless, Y = blue, Z = darker blue

langite.Color: Greenish blue, sky-blue to bluish green
langite.Crystal habit: Crystals scaly, or as crusts; earthy
langite.Pleochroism: X = c = light yellowish greenY = b = blue-greenZ = a = sky blue
langite.Solubility: Insoluble in water, easily soluble in dilute acids or NH4OH
langite.Other characteristics: May be altered to brochantite.  Not radioactive

strashimirite.Crystal habit: Elongated, tabular crystals; crusts; radiating aggregates
strashimirite.Cleavage: Parting at right angle to elongation
strashimirite.Pleochroism: Weak; Y = very pale yellowish green; Z = yellowish green

stolzite.Color: Reddish brown, brown, yellowish gray, smoky gray, straw-yellow, lemon-yellow; may be green, orange, red

triploidite.Color: Red-brown, light pink, yellow-brown; light pink to light brown in transmitted light.
triploidite.Crystal habit: Elongated and striated prismatic crystals; fibrous: columnar to spherulitic
triploidite.Cleavage: On {010}, good; on {120}, fair; on {110}, very poor.

tremolite.Color: White, gray, lavender to pink, light green, light yellow
tremolite.Crystal habit: Elongated prismatic, or flattened crystals; also as fibrous, granular or columnar aggregates
tremolite.Twinning: Simple or multiple, common parallel to {100}; rarely parallel to {001}
tremolite.Cleavage: Perfect on {110} at 56° and 124°; partings on {010} and {100}

tsumebite.Crystal habit: Crusts of intergrown crystals on matrix
tsumebite.Twinning: Almost always twinned.  Twins may be multiple, with serrated re-entrants.
tsumebite.Pleochroism: Faint: X = Y = very pale blue to colorless; Z = robin’s-egg-blue[2][3]
tsumebite.Solubility: Readily soluble in HCl and slowly soluble in HNO3.[4]

triplite.Color: Chestnut to reddish brown, flesh-red, salmon-pink
triplite.Cleavage: Good on {001}, fair on {010}, poor on {100}

carminite.Dana classification: 41 Anhydrous phosphates, arsenates and vanadates containing hydroxyl or halogen
carminite.Crystal habit: Typically bladed crystals, also acicular crystals, in spherical or tufted aggregates and as fibrous or drusy masses
carminite.Pleochroism: strong, X= pale yellowish red; Y=Z= dark carmine red
carminite.Solubility: Slowly soluble in HCl with the separation of PbCl2, and totally soluble in HNO3
carminite.Other characteristics: Carminite is not radioactive. No piezoelectric effect could be detected[2]

carnotite.Color: Bright yellow to lemon-yellow, may be greenish yellow.
carnotite.Crystal habit: Crusts, earthy masses, foliated and granular aggregates.
carnotite.Twinning: On {001} as both twin and composition plane

phenakite.Crystal habit: Tabular, prismatic to acicular crystals often as columnar aggregates, as spherulites and granular

vauxite.Crystal habit: Minute tabular crystals, radial aggregates and nodules

stilpnomelane.Color: Black, greenish black, yellowish bronze, greenish bronze
stilpnomelane.Crystal habit: Platey, scaly and fibrous with comb structures; radiating groups
stilpnomelane.Pleochroism:
X: bright golden yellow to pale yellow
Y and Z: deep reddish brown, to deep green to nearly black

pyrochlore.Color: Black to brown, chocolate-brown, reddish brown, amber-orange, red-orange

santabarbaraite.Cleavage: None, parting along {010} of replaced phase

warikahnite.Color: Pale yellow to colorless; honey-yellow; orange

whiteite.Formula:
Whiteite-(CaFeMg):
CaFe2+Mg2Al2(PO4)4(OH)2·8H2O
Whiteite-(MnFeMg):
Mn2+Fe2+Mg2Al2(PO4)4(OH)2·8H2O
Whiteite-(CaMnMg):

CaMn2+Mg2Al2(PO4)4(OH)2·8H2O
whiteite.Color:
Whiteite-(CaFeMg): Brown, pink-brown or yellow
Whiteite-(MnFeMg): Brown

Whiteite-(CaMnMg): Yellow, light lavender or pink
whiteite.Twinning: Invariably twinned by reflection on {001} producing a pseudo-orthorhombic appearance
whiteite.Cleavage: On {001}. Poor for whiteite-(CaMnMg), but good for the other members of the series (HOM)

whitlockite.Color: Colorless, gray-white, light pink, light yellow
whitlockite.Crystal habit: rhombohedral crystals, often tabular, massive, microcrystalline crusts and as "cave pearls"

willemite.Color: Colorless to white, gray, black, flesh-red, burgundy-red, pink, brown, dark brown, mahogany-brown, honey-yellow, yellow, apple-green, blue, pastel green, light blue, azure-blue
willemite.troostite: zinc is partly replaced by manganese

wüstite.Color: Greyish white to yellow or brown; colorless in thin section

xenotime.Streak: Pale brown, yellowish or reddish, to white

wavellite.Color: Green to yellowish-green and greenish blue and blue. and yellow, brown, white and colorless
wavellite.Crystal habit: Spherical, radial aggregates; striated prisms; crusty to stalactitic
wavellite.Fusibility: Infusable, swells and splits on heating

witherite.Color: Colorless, white, pale gray, with possible tints of pale-yellow, pale-brown, or pale-green
witherite.Crystal habit:
Striated short prismatic crystals, also botryoidal to spherical,
columnar fibrous, granular, massive.
witherite.Ultraviolet: Fluorescent and phosphorescent, short UV=bluish white, long UV=bluish white

zoisite.Color: White, gray, greenish brown, greenish gray, pink, blue, purple
zoisite.Crystal habit: Prismatic crystals with striations; massive to columnar
zoisite.Pleochroism: X = pale pink to red-violet; Y = nearly colorless to bright pink or deep blue; Z = pale yellow to yellow-green

majorite.Space group: Ia3d or tetragonal I41/a for pure MgSiO3
majorite.Crystal habit: Microcrystalline aggregates; acicular to equant grains in narrow veinlets
majorite.Specific gravity: Measured at about 4; 3.51 (calculated for pure MgSiO3)

hausmannite.Crystal habit: Massive – granular – common texture observed in granite and other igneous rock. pseudo octahedral – crystals show an octahedral outline.
hausmannite.Fracture: Uneven – flat surfaces (not cleavage) fractured in an uneven pattern.
hausmannite.Other characteristics: Anisotropism: Distinct,  bireflectance: weak; O = light gray; E = dark gray.

hendricksite.Color: Copper-, bronze brown, dark reddish brown to reddish black
hendricksite.Pleochroism: X = Pale yellow, Y = Z = Light chestnut brown
hendricksite.Common impurities: Ti, Fe, Ca, Ba, Li, Na, F

franklinphilite.Unit cell: a = 5.52, b = 9.56 c = 36.57 [Å]; Z = 6 α = β = γ = essentially 90°
franklinphilite.Pleochroism: Distinct; X = pale yellow; Y = Z = deep brown

euxenite.Luster: Brilliant submetallic, waxy to resinous on fractures
euxenite.Other characteristics: Metamict – originally crystalline, now amorphous due to radiation damage.  Radioactive

mullite.Color: Colorless to pale pink or grey

sugilite.Color: Light brownish-yellow, purple, violet, reddish violet, pale pink, colorless
sugilite.Crystal habit: Prismatic crystals, typically granular to massive

xonotlite.Color: White, grey, pale pink, lemon white, colorless
xonotlite.Ultraviolet: Short UV = weak gray-white Long UV = weak white

yuksporite.Color: Brownish pink to rose-red to straw-yellow
yuksporite.Pleochroism: X pale rose-yellow, Y, Z rose-yellow

zircophyllite.Pleochroism: X = Y = dark yellow; Z = brown

nelenite.Pleochroism: Visible ε = colorless and ω = light brown

boulangerite.Cleavage: Good Distinct on {100}  Indistinct on {001} and {010}
boulangerite.Solubility: Completely soluble in hydrochloric acid Partially soluble in nitric acid

boehmite.Color: White, pale greyish brown; yellowish or reddish when impure; colorless in thin section
boehmite.Crystal habit: Tabular crystal rare, fine grained in pisolitic aggregates or disseminated
boehmite.Cleavage: Very good on {010}, good on {100}, and poor on {001}

buddingtonite.Crystal habit: Compact masses replacing plagioclase as pseudomorphs

faujasite.Crystal habit: Octahedral or rarely trisoctahedral crystals up to 4 mm in size

epsomite.Color: White, grey, colorless, or pink, greenish

tuperssuatsiaite.Pleochroism: Colorless to yellowish brown or reddish brown

ephesite.Space group: C2/c[2] also reported is a triclinic polytype[3]
ephesite.Color: Brownish pink, pearl gray, pale green

pearceite.Pleochroism: RL Pleochroism (in reflected plane polarised light): Very weak in air, fair in oil[3][4]

chalcanthite.Color: Berlin blue to sky blue, greenish blue
chalcanthite.Crystal habit: Typically stalactitic, encrusted, reniform or massive. Natural crystals are rare, but are short prismatic or tabular
chalcanthite.Solubility: Soluble in water, turning it blue

pseudomalachite.Color: Dark emerald green to blackish green
pseudomalachite.Crystal habit: Crystals, which are rare, are prismatic, usually with uneven faces.  Pseudomalachite is commonly compact, reniform or botryoidal, or it may be fibrous or in crusts and films.
pseudomalachite.Streak: Blue green, paler than the mineral
pseudomalachite.Pleochroism: Weak; X = bluish green to pale green; Y = yellowish green; Z = deep bluish green to blue-green
pseudomalachite.Solubility: Soluble in acids but without effervescence (in contrast to malachite which effervesces with warm HCl)

proustite.Crystal habit: Crystals prismatic and scalenohedral, massive, compact
proustite.Diaphaneity: Translucent, darkens when exposed to light

pigeonite.Crystal habit: Prismatic crystals, to 1 cm; granular, massive.
pigeonite.Twinning: Commonly twinned simply or multiply on {100} or {001}
pigeonite.Pleochroism: Weak to moderate; X = colorless, pale green, brown; Y = pale brown, pale brownish green, brownish pink; Z = colorless, pale green, pale yellow

pyrargyrite.Crystal habit: Include prismatic crystals with rhombohedral and scalenohedral faces forming terminations. massive, granular
pyrargyrite.Other characteristics: Darkens upon exposure to light; crystals are frequently striated

celsian.Crystal habit: Short prismatic to acicular crystals, massive
celsian.Twinning: Manebach twins on (001), baveno twins (021), rare lamellar twinning
celsian.Cleavage: Perfect on {001}, good on {010}, poor on {110}

roselite.Crystal habit: Elongated crystals and spherical aggregates and druses
roselite.Twinning: Common as composition plane, contact twins and fourlings
roselite.Pleochroism: (Dark rose) X: Dark rose, Y: Pale rose, Z: Paler rose  (Light rose) X: Pale rose, Y: Paler rose, Z: Palest rose

plancheite.Color: Pale blue, light blue, dark green
plancheite.Pleochroism: X colorless or pale blue, Y colorless or blue, Z blue or dark blue

pseudobrookite.Color: Dark reddish brown, brownish black, black

robertsite.Color: Red, red-brown, deep red, bronzy brown, black
robertsite.Crystal habit: laty to wedge-shaped, pseudorhombohedral crystals; fibrous, in botryoidal to feathery aggregates
robertsite.Pleochroism: Strong, X pale red to pink Y,Z deep red brown

reidite.Crystal habit:
Epitaxial - crystallographic alignment with a precursor mineral,
occurs as inclusions in other minerals.

guettardite.Color: Grayish black; white with reddish internal reflections in polished section

pyrophanite.Crystal habit: Rarely as rosettes of hexagonal plates, typically granular, scaly; occurs as exsolution lamenae in franklinite and spinel

schoepite.Crystal habit: Commonly as tabular equant, to short prismatic crystals; rarely in microcrystalline aggregates
schoepite.Pleochroism: X = almost colorless; Y = Z = lemon-yellow to golden yellow
schoepite.Ultraviolet: Short and long UV = pale green

pickeringite.Color: Colorless, white; may be shades of yellow, green, or red due to impurities
pickeringite.Crystal habit:
Rarely as acicular crystals, radial or matted aggregates; typically as 
incrustations and efflorescences
pickeringite.Common impurities: May contain iron, manganese or cobalt

rosasite.Crystal habit: Acicular crystals as radiating fibrous clusters; botryoidal; mammillary; encrustations
rosasite.Pleochroism: Strong: X = pale emerald green or colourless;  Y = dark emerald green or pale blue; Z = dark emerald green or pale blue
rosasite.Solubility: Effervesces in cold, dilute hydrochloric acid

ulvöspinel.Category: Oxide minerals Spinel group Spinel structural group
ulvöspinel.Crystal habit: Commonly as an exsolution in magnetite

danburite.Colour: Colourless, white, gray, brownish white, straw yellow
danburite.Ultraviolet: Fluorescent and thermoluminescent (red); Short UV=violet blue; Long UV=blue to blue-green

sarcolite.Color: Flesh-pink, flesh-red, red, reddish white, colourless
sarcolite.Common impurities: Ti, Fe, Mn, Mg, Sr, K, Cl, P, S

schmiederite.Crystal habit: Fibrous in radial clusters; may be in crusts; powdery

portlandite.Crystal habit: Hexagonal plates; commonly fibrous, powdery, massive.
portlandite.Solubility: Soluble in water producing an alkaline solution
portlandite.Alters to: Alters to CaCO3 on exposure to CO2 bearing waters

schwertmannite.Space group: Tetragonal H-M symbol: (4/m) Space group: P4/m

lulzacite.Crystal habit: Anhedral aggregates; rarely small euhedral crystals

magnesiopascoite.Solubility: Slowly in waterQuickly in cold, dilute HCl[3]

livingstonite.Color: Blackish gray; in polished section, white; red in transmitted light, with deep red internal reflections
livingstonite.Crystal habit: As needles elongated [010], to 12 cm; also fibrous, massive, columnar, and in globular masses and interlaced needles.

chlorite group.Color: Various shades of green; rarely yellow, red, or white.
chlorite group.Crystal habit: Foliated masses, scaley aggregates, disseminated flakes.

covellite.Color: Indigo-blue or darker, commonly highly iridescent, brass-yellow to deep red
covellite.Crystal habit: Thin platy hexagonal crystals and rosettes also massive to granular.
covellite.Luster: Submetallic, inclining to resinous to dull
covellite.Pleochroism: Marked, deep blue to pale blue

ikaite.Crystal habit: Nearly square prism; pyramidal; sigmoidal: square prism capped with oppositely canted pyramids; massive, tubular (tinolite vr.)
ikaite.Other characteristics: Decomposes into water and calcite above 8 °C[3]

chrysocolla.Color: Blue, cyan (blue-green), green, dark blue to black, brown, rarely yellow

ettringite.Crystal habit: Acicular growth, striated prismatic crystals; fibrous to cottonlike
ettringite.Alters to: Partially dehydration on atmospheric exposure, becomes opaque

nepheline.Color: White, gray, brown, brownish gray, or reddish white

népouite.Color: bright green (typical of nickel bearing silicates) to yellowish or brownish green, depending on nickel content
népouite.Crystal habit: generally massive, also fibrous and microscopic pseudohexagonal platy crystals
népouite.Pleochroism: weak.  X = green to yellow green Z = yellow-green

forsterite.Color: Colorless, green, yellow, yellow green, white
forsterite.Crystal habit: Dipyramidal prisms often tabular, commonly granular or compact massive

gugiaite.Fracture: Uneven – Flat surfaces (not cleavage) fractured in an uneven pattern

pyrophyllite.Color: Brown green, brownish yellow, greenish, gray green, gray white
pyrophyllite.Crystal habit:
Compact spherulitic aggregates of needlelike radiating crystals; as
fine grained foliated laminae, granular, massive

orthoclase.Color: Colorless, greenish, greyish yellow, white, pink
orthoclase.Crystal habit: Can be anhedral or euhedral. Grains are commonly elongate with a tabular appearance.
orthoclase.Twinning: Typically displays Carlsbad twinning. Baveno and manebach twins have also been reported in orthoclase.
orthoclase.Cleavage: Has perfect cleavage on {001} and good cleavage on {010}. Cleavages intersect at 90°. It can be difficult to see cleavage in thin section due to orthoclase's low relief.
orthoclase.Diagnostic features: Distinguishable from microcline by a lack in gridiron twinning. Distinguishable from sanidine by a larger 2Vx.
orthoclase.Other characteristics: Low negative relief;alters to sericite or clay (commonly)

roscoelite.Crystal habit: scales, fans, druses, rosettes, fibrous or felted aggregate.

phlogopite.Color: Brown, brownish red, dark brown, yellow, yellowish brown, green, white and gray
phlogopite.Crystal habit: Tabular, scaly masses, rarely perfect phenocryst tablets
phlogopite.Luster: Pearly, sometimes slightly metallic on cleavage surfaces

telluric iron.Color: Steel-gray to iron-black, white in polished section
telluric iron.Crystal habit: Massive, as interstitial blebs, rare as crystals

siegenite.Category: Sulfide mineral Thiospinel group Spinel structural group

hydrotalcite.Crystal class: 3R polytype: Hexagonal scalenohedral (3m) H-M symbol: (3 2/m) 2H polytype: Dihexagonal dipyramidal (6/mmm)
hydrotalcite.Crystal habit: Subhedral platey crystals, lamellar-fibrous, rarely euhedral prismatic; commonly foliated, massive

serpierite.Crystal habit: Crusts and tufted aggregates of tiny lathlike crystals
serpierite.Streak: White, pale blue or greenish white
serpierite.Pleochroism: X = pale green; Y = bluish green; Z = bluish green

siderite.Color: Pale yellow to tan, grey, brown, green, red, black and sometimes nearly colorless
siderite.Crystal habit: Tabular crystals, often curved; botryoidal to massive
siderite.Luster: Vitreous, may be silky to pearly

tantalite.Color: Dark black, iron-black to dark brown, reddish brown

nitratine.Crystal habit: Granular – Generally occurs as anhedral to subhedral crystals in matrix; massive – Uniformly indistinguishable crystals forming large masses
nitratine.Tenacity: Sectile – curved shavings or scrapings produced by a knife blade

tobermorite.Crystal habit: As minute laths; fibrous bundles, rosettes or sheaves, radiating or plumose, fine granular, massive.
tobermorite.Ultraviolet: Fluorescent, Short UV:weak white to yellow, Long UV:weak white to yellow

trona.Color: Colorless (in transmitted light) or white, grey-white, also grey to yellowish grey, light yellow
trona.Other characteristics: May fluoresce under short wavelength ultraviolet

tridymite.Other characteristics: non-radioactive, non-magnetic; fluorescent, short UV=dark red

thorianite.Crystal habit: Cubic crystals, usually rounded to some degree in detrital deposits

pyromorphite.Color: Dark green to grass-green or green, yellow, yellow-orange, reddish orange, yellow-brown, greenish-yellow or yellowish-green, shades of brown, tan, grayish, white and may be colorless; colourless or faintly tinted in transmitted light.
pyromorphite.Crystal habit: Prismatic to acicular crystals, globular to reniform
pyromorphite.Ultraviolet: May fluoresce yellow to orange under LW and SW UV

uvarovite.Other characteristics: Fluorescent red in both short and long UV

mackinawite.Crystal habit: As well-formed thin tabular crystals; massive, fine-feathery

zirconolite.Crystal system: 2M polytype: monoclinic 3O polytype: orthorhombic 3T polytype: trigonal
zirconolite.Crystal class: 2M polytype: prismatic (2/m) 3O polytype: dipyramidal (mmm (2/m 2/m 2/m)) 3T polytype: trapezohedral (3 2)

natron.Colour: Colourless to white, greyish, yellowish; colourless in transmitted light.
natron.Cleavage: On {001} distinct; on {010} imperfect; on {110} in traces.

uraninite.Color: Steel-black to velvet-black, brownish black, pale gray to pale green; in transmitted light, pale green, pale yellow to deep brown and green-gray (thin fragments)
uraninite.Crystal habit: Massive, botryoidal, granular. Octahedral crystals uncommon.

paramelaconite.Color: Black to black with a slight purple tintWhite with pinkish brown tint in reflected light
paramelaconite.Crystal habit: Occurs as striated prismatic crystals; massive

omphacite.Color: Green to dark green; colorless to pale green in thin section
omphacite.Crystal habit: Rarely in rough crystals; anhedral, granular to massive
omphacite.Twinning: Single and polysynthetic twinning common on {100}
omphacite.Pleochroism: Weak; X = colorless; Y = very pale green; Z = very pale green, blue-green

painite.Crystal class: Dipyramidal (6/m) (same H-M symbol), although earlier reported as hexagonal (6)[3]
painite.Pleochroism:
Ruby-red parallel to [0001]; pale brownish orange or pale
red-orange at right angles to [0001]

carlsbergite.Color: Light gray in reflected light with rose tint
carlsbergite.Crystal habit: Oriented microscopic platelets, irregular to feathery grains

quetzalcoatlite.Crystal habit: needle-like hexagonal crystals, crystalline crusts, sprays
quetzalcoatlite.Solubility: Insoluble in water, soluble in cold HCl and cold HNO3. Decomposes in KOH when heated

sauconite.Color: Reddish brown, brown, brownish yellow, mottled
sauconite.Crystal habit: Clayey; as small micaceous plates in laminated to compact masses

scolecite.Color: Colorless white, pink, salmon, red or green
scolecite.Crystal habit: Thin prismatic needles, radiating groups and fibrous masses
scolecite.Twinning: Common on {100}, twin axis [001], rare on {001} and {110} [2]
scolecite.Pleochroism: X: colourless Y: colourless Z: colourless [3]
scolecite.Other characteristics: Pyroelectric and piezoelectric, sometimes fluorescent yellow to brown in LW and SW UV. Not radioactive.

riebeckite.Color: Black, dark blue; dark blue to yellow-green in thin section
riebeckite.Crystal habit: As prismatic crystals, commonly fibrous, asbestiform; earthy, massive
riebeckite.Twinning: Simple or multiple twinning parallel to {100}
riebeckite.Cleavage: Perfect on {110}, intersecting at 56° and 124°; partings on {100} and {010}
riebeckite.Pleochroism: X = blue, indigo; Y = yellowish green, yellow brown; Z = dark blue

scapolite.Color: Pink, red, blue, brown, white, grey, colourless, green, yellow, orange, purple
scapolite.Ultraviolet: Inert to strong pink, orange and yellow

mendipite.Color: Colorless to white, brownish cream, grey, yellowish, pink, red, or blue; nearly colorless in transmitted light.
mendipite.Crystal habit: Columnar or fibrous aggregates, often radiated, and cleavable masses.
mendipite.Luster: Pearly to silky on cleavages; resinous to adamantine on fractures.
mendipite.Solubility: Soluble in dilute nitric acid, HNO3

mimetite.Color: Pale to bright yellow, yellowish brown, yellow-orange, white, may be colorless
mimetite.Crystal habit: Prismatic to acicular crystals; reniform, botryoidal, globular,

axinite.Color: Reddish brown to yellow to colorless. Blue, violet, grey.

jeremejevite.Color: Colorless, white, yellowish, blue, light yellow brown, aquamarine blue, rarely violet; colourless in transmitted light

azurite.Color: Azure-blue, dark to pale blue; pale blue in transmitted light
azurite.Cleavage: Perfect on {011}, fair on {100}, poor on {110}

biotite.Twinning: Common on the [310], less common on the {001}
biotite.Dispersion: r < v (Fe rich); r > v weak (Mg rich)

cuprospinel.Crystal habit: Irregular grains, laminae intergrown with hematite

dolomite (mineral).Color: White, grey to pink, reddish-white, brownish-white; colourless in transmitted light
dolomite (mineral).Crystal habit: Tabular crystals, often with curved faces, also columnar, stalactitic, granular, massive.
dolomite (mineral).Cleavage: 3 directions of cleavage not at right angles
dolomite (mineral).Other characteristics: May fluoresce white to pink under UV; triboluminescent. Ksp values vary between 10−19 and 10−17

kyanite.Color: Blue, white, rarely green, light gray to gray, rarely yellow, pink, orange, and black, can be zoned
kyanite.Mohs scale: 4.5–5 parallel to one axis  6.5–7 perpendicular to that axis
kyanite.Pleochroism: Trichroic, colorless to pale blue to blue

monazite.Color: Orange, purple, reddish brown, brown, pale yellow, pink, blue, green, gray,
monazite.Crystal habit: Commonly as prismatic or wedge-shaped crystals
monazite.Other characteristics: Radioactive if uranium and/or thorium-rich, dull brown cathodoluminescence, paramagnetic

moissanite.Crystal habit: Generally found as inclusions in other minerals
moissanite.Fracture: Conchoidal – fractures developed in brittle materials characterized by smoothly curving surfaces, e.g., quartz

montmorillonite.Color: White, pale pink, blue, yellow, red, green
montmorillonite.Crystal habit: Compact masses of lamellar or globular microcrystalline aggregates

wulfenite.Color: Orange-yellow, yellow, honey-yellow, reddish-orange, rarely colorless, grey, brown, olive-green and even black

labradorite.Color: Gray, gray-white, brown, greenish, pale green, blue, orange, pink, yellow, colorless
labradorite.Crystal habit: Crystals typically thin and tabular, rhombic in cross section, striated; massive
labradorite.Twinning: Common by albite, pericline, Carlsbad, Baveno, or Manebach twin laws
labradorite.Cleavage: Perfect on {001}, less perfect on {010}, intersecting at near 90°; distinct on {110}

cassiterite.Color: Black, brownish black, reddish brown, brown, red, yellow, gray, white; rarely colorless
cassiterite.Crystal habit: Pyramidic, prismatic, radially fibrous botryoidal crusts and concretionary masses; coarse to fine granular, massive
cassiterite.Twinning: Very common on {011}, as contact and penetration twins, geniculated; lamellar
cassiterite.Luster: Adamantine to adamantine metallic, splendent; may be greasy on fractures
cassiterite.Diaphaneity: Transparent when light colored, dark material nearly opaque; commonly zoned
cassiterite.Pleochroism: Pleochroic haloes have been observed. Dichroic in yellow, green, red, brown, usually weak, or absent, but strong at times

pyrolusite.Color: Darkish, black to lighter grey, sometimes bluish
pyrolusite.Crystal habit: Granular to massive: botryoidal. Crystals rare

ringwoodite.Colour: Deep blue, also red, violet, or colourless (pure Mg2SiO4)

struvite.Color: Colorless, white (dehydrated), yellow or brownish, light gray
struvite.Solubility: Slightly soluble, dehydrates in dry, warm air

stibnite.Color: Lead-gray, tarnishing blackish or iridescent; in polished section, white
stibnite.Crystal habit: Massive, radiating and elongated crystals. Massive and granular
stibnite.Cleavage: Perfect and easy on {010}; imperfect on {100} and {110}
stibnite.Tenacity: Highly flexible but not elastic; slightly sectile

stilbite.Crystal habit: Thin tabular, aggregates sheaf-like or in bow-ties, also fibrous and globular.
stilbite.Fusibility: Easily fused by blowpipe (~1050 °C) to produce a white "enamel"[6]

titanite.Colour: Reddish brown, brown, gray, black, yellow, green, or red, colourless
titanite.Twinning: Contact and penetration on {100}, lamellar on {221}
titanite.Pleochroism: Strong: X = nearly colorless; Y = yellow to green; Z = red to yellow-orange

tranquillityite.Color: Gray, dark red-brown in transmitted light
tranquillityite.Crystal habit: Lath shaped grains generally found as inclusions in other minerals or interstitial (<0.1% in weight)[3]
tranquillityite.Common impurities: Y, Hf, Al, Cr, Nb, Nd, Mn, Ca

torbernite.Formula mass: 641 – 713 g/mol, depending the degree of water loss
torbernite.Crystal habit: Tabular crystals; Foliated to earthy masses and encrustations

troilite.Crystal habit: Massive, granular; nodular; platey to tabular

taranakite.Solubility: Insoluble in water Slightly soluble in acids[2]

vanadinite.Colour: Bright red, orange-red, red-brown, brown, yellow, whitish, grey or colourless or weakly tinted in transmitted light; pale straw-yellow;. may be concentrically zoned
vanadinite.Crystal habit: Prismatic or nodular; may be acicular, hairlike, fibrous; rarely rounded, globular

variscite.Color: Pale to emerald-green (pale green in transmitted light), green, blue green, yellow green, pale shades of brown or yellow, rarely red and colourless to white

zinnwaldite.Color: Gray-brown, yellow-brown, pale violet, dark green, color zoning common
zinnwaldite.Crystal habit: Well-formed short prismatic or tabular crystals, pseudohexagonal, in rosettes or fan-shaped groups; lamellar or scaly aggregates; disseminated.
zinnwaldite.Pleochroism: Distinct, X = colorless to yellow-brown; Y = gray-brown; Z = colorless to gray-brown

hauyne.Color: Blue, white, gray, yellow, green, pink
hauyne.Other characteristics: May fluoresce orange to pink under longwave ultraviolet light[5][6]

rhodonite.Color: Pink, rose-pink to brownish red, red, gray and yellow
rhodonite.Alters to: Exterior commonly black from manganese oxides

schreibersite.Color: Silver-white to tin-white, tarnishes brass-yellow or brown
schreibersite.Crystal habit: Rarely in crystals, hoppered, plates, tablets, rods or needles

aragonite.IMA symbol: Arg (not to be confused with arginine)
aragonite.Color: Can come in a variety of colors, but commonly red or white
aragonite.Crystal habit: Commonly dendritic or pseudo-hexagonal; can also be acicular, tabular, prismatic, coral-like
aragonite.Twinning: Cyclic on {110}, forms pseudohexagonal aggregates. If polysynthetic, forms fine striations parallel to [110].
aragonite.Solubility: Soluble in acids, and saltwater (but takes longer)
aragonite.Other characteristics: Thermodynamically unstable, Morphs slowly back into calcite

corundum.Color: Colorless, gray, golden-brown, brown; purple, pink to red, orange, yellow, green, blue, violet; may be color zoned, asteriated mainly grey and brown
corundum.Crystal habit: Steep bipyramidal, tabular, prismatic, rhombohedral crystals, massive or granular
corundum.Alters to: May alter to mica on surfaces causing a decrease in hardness
corundum.Other characteristics: May fluoresce or phosphoresce under UV light
corundum.Emery: Black granular corundum intimately mixed with magnetite, hematite, or hercynite

goethite.Color: Yellowish to reddish to dark brown or black
goethite.Crystal habit: radial acicular, mammillary, botryoidal, stalactitic, massive, as encrustation, as pseudomorph; may be banded or iridescent
goethite.Streak: Brown, brownish yellow to orange yellow

halite.Color: Colorless or white when pure. Impurities produce any color but usually yellow, gray, black, brown, red (Depends on isotopes and purity for various colours)[2]
halite.Crystal habit: Predominantly cubes and in massive sedimentary beds, but also granular, fibrous and compact

halloysite.Color: White; grey, green, blue, yellow, red from included impurities.

jadarite.Ultraviolet: Weak pink to orange under UV

strontianite.Color: Colourless, white, gray, light yellow, green or brown; colourless in transmitted light
strontianite.Crystal habit: Prismatic, acicular, pseudo hexagonal, columnar to fibrous, granular, massive
strontianite.Twinning: Very common, usually contact, rarely penetration, also repeated
strontianite.Specific gravity: 3.74 to 3.78 Transparent versions are heavier than the other ones

todorokite.Color: Dark brown or brownish black, brown in transmitted light
todorokite.Luster: Metallic to dull, silky in aggregates
todorokite.Diaphaneity: Opaque, transparent in very thin slivers
todorokite.Pleochroism: X = dark brown, Z = yellowish brown[4]

muscovite.Twinning: Common on the [310], less common on the {001}

petalite.Color: Colorless, grey, yellow, pink, to white
petalite.Crystal habit: Tabular prismatic crystals and columnar masses
petalite.Cleavage: Perfect on {001}, poor on {201} with 38.5° angle between the two

saponite.Pleochroism: X = colorless, light yellow to green-brown; Y = Z = colorless, greenish brown to dark brown

celestine (mineral).Formula: SrSO4 sometimes contains minor calcium and/or barium
celestine (mineral).Color: White, pink, pale green, pale brown, black, pale blue, reddish, greyish; colourless or lightly tinted in transmitted light
celestine (mineral).Crystal habit: Tabular to pyramidal crystals, also fibrous, lamellar, earthy, massive granular
celestine (mineral).Cleavage: Perfect on {001}, good on {210}, poor on {010}
celestine (mineral).Ultraviolet: yellow, white blue (both short and long UV)

rutile.Color: Brown, reddish brown, blood red, red, brownish yellow, pale yellow, yellow, pale blue, violet, rarely grass-green, grayish black; black if high in Nb–Ta
rutile.Crystal habit: Acicular to Prismatic crystals, elongated and striated parallel to [001]
rutile.Twinning: Common on {011}, or {031}; as contact twins with two, six, or eight individuals, cyclic, polysynthetic

birnessite.Other characteristics: Identification by optical properties is impossible.

chromite.Category: Oxide minerals Spinel group Spinel structural group
chromite.Color: Black to brownish black; brown to brownish black on thin edges in transmitted light

columbite.Crystal habit: Massive – Granular – Common texture observed in granite and other igneous rock; Striated - Parallel lines on crystal surface or cleavage face.
columbite.Fracture: Sub Conchoidal: Fractures developed in brittle materials characterized by semi-curving surfaces.

kamacite.Crystal habit: Massive – uniformly indistinguishable crystals forming large masses
kamacite.Fracture: Hackly – Jagged, torn surfaces, (e.g. fractured metals).

chrysoberyl.Color: Various shades of green, emerald-green yellow, blue, brownish to greenish black, may be raspberry-red under incandescent light when chromian; colorless, pale shades of yellow, green, or red in transmitted light
chrysoberyl.Crystal habit: Crystals tabular or short prismatic, prominently striated
chrysoberyl.Twinning: Contact and penetration twins common, often repeated forming rosette structures
chrysoberyl.Cleavage: Distinct on {110}, imperfect on {010}, poor on {001}
chrysoberyl.Pleochroism: X = red; Y = yellow-orange; Z = emerald-green

lonsdaleite.Color: Gray in crystals, pale yellowish to brown in broken fragments

perovskite.Color: Black, reddish brown, pale yellow, yellowish orange
perovskite.Crystal habit: Pseudo cubic – crystals show a cubic outline
perovskite.Luster: Adamantine to metallic; may be dull

chalcopyrite.Color: Brass yellow, may have iridescent purplish tarnish.
chalcopyrite.Crystal habit: Predominantly the disphenoid and resembles a tetrahedron, commonly massive, and sometimes botryoidal.

sodalite.Color: Rich royal blue, green, yellow, violet, white veining common
sodalite.Ultraviolet: Bright red-orange cathodoluminescence and fluorescence under LW and SW UV, with yellowish phosphorescence; may be photochromic in magentas
sodalite.Fusibility: Easily to a colourless glass; sodium yellow flame
sodalite.Solubility: Soluble in hydrochloric acid and nitric acid
sodalite.Hackmanite: Tenebrescent; violet-red or green fading to white

galena.Crystal habit: Cubes and octahedra, blocky, tabular and sometimes skeletal crystals

wollastonite.Crystal habit: Rare as tabular crystals—commonly massive in lamellar, radiating, compact and fibrous aggregates.
wollastonite.Cleavage: Perfect in two directions at near 90°
wollastonite.Luster: Vitreous or dull to pearly on cleavage surfaces
wollastonite.Solubility: Soluble in HCl, insoluble in water
wollastonite.Other characteristics:
Heat of formation (@298): −89.61kJ
Gibbs free energy: 41.78kJ

vivianite.Color: Colorless, very pale green, becoming dark blue, dark greenish blue, indigo-blue, then black with oxidation
vivianite.Crystal habit: Flattened, elongated prismatic crystals, may be rounded or corroded; as stellate groups, incrustations, concretionary, earthy or powdery
vivianite.Luster: Vitreous, pearly on the cleavage, dull when earthy
vivianite.Streak: White, altering to dark blue, brown
vivianite.Pleochroism: Visible; X = blue, deep blue, Indigo-blue; Y = pale yellowish green, pale bluish green, yellow-green; Z = pale yellowish green, olive-yellow

ulexite.Cleavage: Perfect on {010} good on {110} poor on {110}
ulexite.Luster: Vitreous; silky or satiny in fibrous aggregates
ulexite.Ultraviolet: Depending on fluorescent impurities, ulexite may fluoresce yellow, greenish yellow, cream, white under short waves and long waves UV
ulexite.Other characteristics: Parallel fibrous masses can act as fiber optical light pipes

orpiment.Color: Lemon-yellow to golden or brownish yellow
orpiment.Crystal habit: Commonly in foliated columnar or fibrous aggregates; may be reniform or botryoidal; also granular or powdery; rarely as prismatic crystals
orpiment.Pleochroism: In reflected light, strong, white to pale gray with reddish tint; in transmitted light, Y = yellow, Z = greenish yellow

rhodochrosite.Color: Pink, rose, rose-red, red, cherry-red, yellow, yellowish grey, grey, cinnamon-brown, white, may be banded; colourless to pale rose in transmitted light.
rhodochrosite.Crystal habit: Rhombohedral and scalenohedral crystals; also commonly bladed, columnar, stalactitic, botryoidal, granular or massive

scheelite.Color: Colorless, white, gray, dark brown, brown, tan, pale yellow, yellow-orange, golden yellow, pale shades of orange, red, green, etc.; colorless in transmitted light and may be compositionally color zoned
scheelite.Twinning: Common, penetration and contact twins, composition plane {110} or {001}
scheelite.Cleavage: On {101}, distinct; on {112}, interrupted; on {001}, indistinct
scheelite.Pleochroism: Definite dichoric in yellow (yellow to orange-brown)
scheelite.Solubility: Soluble in alkalis. Insoluble in acids
scheelite.Other characteristics: Fluorescence under short-wave UV is bright blue, bluish white to yellow.  Specimens with more molybdenum tend to fluoresce white to yellow, similar to powellite. Occasionally fluoresces red under mid-wave UV.

apatite.Color: Transparent to translucent, usually green, less often colorless, yellow, blue to violet, pink, brown.[3]
apatite.Crystal habit: Tabular, prismatic crystals, massive, compact or granular
apatite.Pleochroism: Blue stones – strong, blue and yellow to colorless. Other colors are weak to very weak.[3]
apatite.Ultraviolet: Yellow stones – purplish-pink, which is stronger in long wave; blue stones – blue to light-blue in both long and short wave; green stones – greenish-yellow, which is stronger in long wave; violet stones – greenish-yellow in long wave, light-purple in short wave.[3]

cinnabar.Color: Cochineal-red, towards brownish red and lead-gray
cinnabar.Crystal habit: Rhombohedral to tabular; granular to massive and as incrustations

chrysotile.Crystal system: Monoclinic: clinochrysotile (most common)Orthorhombic: orthochrysotile and parachrysotile (both rare)
chrysotile.Diagnostic features: White to grayish green thin, flexible curved fiber
chrysotile.Solubility: Insoluble in waterFibres degrade in dilute acid

hydroxyapatite.Color: Colorless, white, gray, yellow, yellowish green
hydroxyapatite.Crystal habit: As tabular crystals and as stalagmites, nodules, in crystalline to massive crusts

jadeite.Color: Apple-green, emerald-green, bluish green, leek-green, purplish blue, greenish white, white, black, may show green spots, rarely blue or violet; colorless in thin section. Often also banded.
jadeite.Crystal habit: Commonly massive, or fibrous, granular; prismatic crystals rare
jadeite.Twinning: Single and lamellar twinning on [100] and [001]
jadeite.Ultraviolet: Dark colors are generally inert. Light green – inert to weak white in long wave, generally inert in short wave; light yellow – inert to weak green in long wave, generally inert in short wave; white – inert to weak  in long wave, generally inert in short wave; light purple – inert to weak white or weak brownish red in long wave, generally inert in short wave; some dyed lavender colors – moderate to strong orange in long wave, weaker in short wave[2]

sepiolite.Color: Grayish white, white, white with a yellowish or reddish tinge; bluish green
sepiolite.Crystal habit: Compact nodular, earthy, clayey, massive; rarely fine fibrous along [001]
sepiolite.Specific gravity: 2; dry porous masses float on water

spodumene.Color: Highly variable: white, colorless, gray, pink, lilac, violet, yellow and green, may be bicolored; emerald green – hiddenite; lilac – kunzite; yellow – triphane
spodumene.Crystal habit: prismatic, generally flattened and elongated, striated parallel to {100}, commonly massive
spodumene.Pleochroism: Strong in kunzite: α-purple, γ-colorless; hiddenite: α-green, γ-colorless

spinel.Category:
Oxide minerals
Spinel group
Spinel structural group
spinel.Color: Various; red, pink, blue, lavender/violet, dark green, brown, black, colourless
spinel.Crystal habit: Octahedral or flat triangular plates caused by twinning
spinel.Specific gravity: (Depending on the composition) The rare Zn-rich spinel can be as high as 4.40, otherwise it averages from 3.58 to 3.61.
spinel.Other characteristics: Weak to medium magnetic, sometimes fluorescent (red synthetic yes, natural red sometimes)

lepidolite.Color: Pink, light purple, purple, rose-red, violet-gray, yellowish, white, colorless other colors possible but are rare.
lepidolite.Crystal habit: Tabular to prismatic pseudohexagonal crystals, scaly aggregates and massive
lepidolite.Pleochroism: X = almost colorless; Y = Z = pink, pale violet

vermiculite.Color: Colorless, white, yellow, green, brown, black
vermiculite.Crystal habit: As large crystalline plates to clay-sized particles; lamellar to scaley
vermiculite.Luster: Greasy or vitreous (pearly at cleavage planes)
vermiculite.Streak: White or yellowish, translucent, shiny, light-brown or greenish in color, in some cases. For example, palabora vermuculite.
vermiculite.Pleochroism: X in paler shades than Y and Z

pyrrhotite.Crystal habit: Tabular or prismatic in hexagonal prisms; massive to granular
pyrrhotite.Other characteristics: Weakly magnetic, strongly magnetic on heating; non-luminescent, non-radioactive

realgar.Color: Red to yellow-orange; in polished section, pale gray, with abundant yellow to red internal reflections
realgar.Crystal habit: Prismatic striated crystals; more commonly massive, coarse to fine granular, or as incrustations
realgar.Pleochroism: Nearly colorless to pale golden yellow
realgar.Other characteristics:
Toxic and carcinogenic.
Disintegrates on long exposure to light to a powder composed of pararealgar or arsenolite and orpiment.

hematite.Color: Metallic grey, dull to bright "rust-red" in earthy, compact, fine-grained material, steel-grey to black in crystals and massively crystalline ores
hematite.Crystal habit: Tabular to thick crystals; micaceous or platy, commonly in rosettes; radiating fibrous, reniform, botryoidal or stalactitic masses, columnar; earthy, granular, oolitic
hematite.Cleavage: None, may show partings on {0001} and {1011}
hematite.Pleochroism: O: brownish red; E: yellowish red

fluorite.Color: Colorless, although samples are often deeply colored owing to impurities; Purple, lilac, golden-yellow, green, blue, pink, champagne, brown.
fluorite.Crystal habit: Well-formed coarse sized crystals; also nodular, botryoidal, rarely columnar or fibrous; granular, massive
fluorite.Specific gravity: 3.175–3.184; to 3.56 if high in rare-earth elements
fluorite.Optical properties: Isotropic; weak anomalous anisotropism; moderate relief
fluorite.Solubility: slightly water soluble and in hot hydrochloric acid
fluorite.Other characteristics: May be fluorescent, phosphorescent, thermoluminescent, and/or triboluminescent

serpentine subgroup.Formula: X3Si2O5(OH)4,with X = Mg2+, Fe2+, Ni2+, Mn2+, Zn2+
serpentine subgroup.Color: Green, yellowish-green, blueish-gray (antigorite)Green, brown, light yellow to white (lizardite)Greyish green to white (chrysotile)
serpentine subgroup.Ultraviolet: SWUV: inert to weak blue; LWUV: inert to weak green

baryte.Color: Colorless, white, light shades of blue, yellow, grey, brown
baryte.Crystal habit: Tabular parallel to base, fibrous, nodular to massive
baryte.Cleavage: Perfect cleavage parallel to base and prism faces: {001} Perfect, {210} Perfect, {010} Imperfect
baryte.Diagnostic features: white color, high specific gravity, characteristic cleavage and crystals

palygorskite.Crystal habit: Commonly fibrous, tangled mats known as mountain leather. Individual, small crystals are lath-shaped[3]
palygorskite.Pleochroism: X= pale yellow Y=Z= pale yellow-green[3]

magnesite.Color: Colorless, white, pale yellow, pale brown, faintly pink, lilac-rose
magnesite.Crystal habit: Usually massive, rarely as rhombohedrons or hexagonal prisms
magnesite.Other characteristics: May exhibit pale green to pale blue fluorescence and phosphorescence under UV; triboluminescent

plagioclase.Refractive index: Albite: nα 1.527, nβ 1.532 nγ 1.538Anorthite: nα 1.577 nβ 1.585 nγ 1.590[2]
plagioclase.Solubility: Albite insoluble in HCl, anorthite decomposed by HCl[2]

beryl.Color: Green, blue, yellow, colorless, pink, and others
beryl.Crystal habit: Prismatic to tabular crystals; radial, columnar; granular to compact massive
beryl.Ultraviolet: None (some fracture-filling materials used to improve emerald's clarity do fluoresce, but the stone itself does not). Morganite has weak violet fluorescence.

malachite.Color: Bright green, dark green, blackish green, with crystals deeper shades of green, even very dark to nearly black commonly banded in masses; green to yellowish green in transmitted light
malachite.Crystal habit: Massive, botryoidal, stalactitic, crystals are acicular to tabular prismatic
malachite.Twinning: Common as contact or penetration twins on {100} and {201}. Polysynthetic twinning also present.
malachite.Luster: Adamantine to vitreous; silky if fibrous; dull to earthy if massive

topaz.Color: Colorless (if there are no impurities), white, blue, brown, orange, gray, yellow, yellowish brown, green, pink, reddish pink or even red
topaz.Pleochroism: Weak in thick sections X = yellow; Y = yellow, violet, reddish; Z = violet, bluish, yellow, pink

ilmenite.Color: Iron-black; gray with a brownish tint in reflected light
ilmenite.Crystal habit: Granular to massive and lamellar exsolutions in hematite or magnetite
ilmenite.Birefringence: Strong; O: pinkish brown, E: dark brown (bireflectance)

zircon.Color: Reddish brown, yellow, green, blue, gray, colorless; in thin section, colorless to pale brown
zircon.Crystal habit: tabular to prismatic crystals, irregular grains, massive
zircon.Twinning: On {101}. Crystals shocked by meteorite impact show polysynthetic twins on {112}
zircon.Luster: Vitreous to adamantine; greasy when metamict.
zircon.Fusibility: close to 2,550 °C depend on Hf,Th,U,H,etc... concentrations.
zircon.Other characteristics: Fluorescent and  radioactive,May form pleochroic halos,Relief: high

mica.Color: purple, rosy, silver, gray (lepidolite); dark green, brown, black (biotite); yellowish-brown, green-white (phlogopite); colorless, transparent (muscovite)

talc.Color: Light to dark green, brown, white, grey, colorless
talc.Crystal habit: Foliated to fibrous masses, rare as platey to pyramidal crystals
talc.Fracture: Flat surfaces (not cleavage), fracture in an uneven pattern
talc.Ultraviolet: Short UV: orange yellow; long UV: yellow

gypsum.Color: Colorless (in transmitted light) to white; often tinged other hues due to impurities; may be yellow, tan, blue, pink, dark brown, reddish brown or gray
gypsum.Crystal habit: Massive, flat. Elongated and generally prismatic crystals
gypsum.Luster: Vitreous to silky, pearly, or waxy

sphalerite.Color: Light to dark brown, red-brown, yellow, red, green, light blue, black and colourless.
sphalerite.Crystal habit: Euhedral crystals – occurs as well-formed crystals showing good external form. Granular – generally occurs as anhedral to subhedral crystals in matrix.
sphalerite.Twinning: Simple contact twins or complex lamellar forms, twin axis [111]
sphalerite.Diaphaneity: Transparent to translucent, opaque when iron-rich

calcite.Color: Typically colorless or creamy white - may have shades of brownish colors
calcite.Crystal habit: Botryoidal, concretionary, druse, globular, granular, massive, rhombohedral, scalenohedral, stalactitic
calcite.Cleavage: Perfect on {1011} three directions with angle of 74° 55'[1]
calcite.Luster: Vitreous to pearly on cleavage surfaces
calcite.Other characteristics: May fluoresce red, blue, yellow, and other colors under either SW and LW UV; phosphorescent

garnet.Color: virtually all colors, blue is rare
garnet.Diaphaneity: Can form with any diaphaneity, translucent is common
garnet.Optical properties: Single refractive, often anomalous double refractive[2]

tourmaline.Color: Most commonly black, but can range from colorless to brown, red, orange, yellow, green, blue, violet, pink, or hues in-between. It can also be bi-colored, or even tri-colored. Rarely, it can be found as neon green or electric blue.
tourmaline.Crystal habit: Parallel and elongated; acicular prisms, sometimes radiating; massive; scattered grains (in granite)
tourmaline.Birefringence: −0.018 to −0.040; typically about −0.020 but in dark stones it may reach −0.040[1]
tourmaline.Pleochroism:
Typically moderate to strong[1]
Red: definite; dark red, light red
Green: strong; dark green, yellow-green
Brown: definite; dark brown, light brown
Blue: strong; dark blue, light blue
tourmaline.Ultraviolet: Pink stones; inert to very weak red to violet in long and short wave[1]
tourmaline.Absorption spectra: Strong narrow band at 498 nm, and almost complete absorption of red down to 640 nm in blue and green stones; red and pink stones show lines at 458 and 451 nm, as well as a broad band in the green spectrum[1]

pyrite.Color: Pale brass-yellow reflective; tarnishes darker and iridescent
pyrite.Crystal habit: Cubic, faces may be striated, but also frequently octahedral and pyritohedral. Often inter-grown, massive, radiated, granular, globular, and stalactitic.

magnetite.Color: Black, gray with brownish tint in reflected sun
magnetite.Twinning: On {Ill} as both twin and composition plane, the spinel law, as contact twins
magnetite.Lodestone: Magnetic with definite north and south poles

turquoise.Cleavage: Perfect on {001}, good on {010}, but cleavage rarely seen

kaolinite.Formula: Al2Si2O5(OH)4, or in oxide notation: Al2O3·2SiO2·2H2O
kaolinite.Color: White to cream, sometimes red, blue or brown tints from impurities and pale-yellow; also often stained various hues, tans and browns being common.
kaolinite.Crystal habit: Rarely as crystals, thin plates or stacked. More commonly as microscopic pseudohexagonal plates and clusters of plates, aggregated into compact, claylike masses.

graphite.Color: Iron-black to steel-gray; deep blue in transmitted light
graphite.Crystal habit: Tabular, six-sided foliated masses, granular to compacted masses
graphite.Fracture: Flaky, otherwise rough when not on cleavage
graphite.Diaphaneity: Opaque, transparent only in extremely thin flakes
graphite.Solubility: Soluble in molten nickel, warm chlorosulfuric acid[2]
graphite.Other characteristics: strongly anisotropic, conducts electricity, greasy feel, readily marks

quartz.Color: Colorless, pink, orange, white, green, yellow, blue, purple, dark brown, or black
quartz.Crystal habit: 6-sided prism ending in 6-sided pyramid (typical), drusy, fine-grained to microcrystalline, massive
quartz.Twinning: Common Dauphine law, Brazil law, and Japan law
quartz.Luster: Vitreous – waxy to dull when massive
quartz.Solubility: Insoluble at STP; 1 ppmmass at 400 °C and 500  lb/in2 to 2600 ppmmass at 500 °C and 1500 lb/in2[3]
quartz.Other characteristics: Lattice: hexagonal, piezoelectric, may be triboluminescent, chiral (hence optically active if not racemic)
